captions.text: Travelling.
Like no other desire, it lures us away from our daily routine,
into far away countries and to the other side of the world.
Australia has always fascinated me.
When I was young, I had a dream: Travelling abroad for a year,
driving my own car and just following my nose.
If you really believe in your dreams, they will come true.
One year ago, I packed my apartment into little boxes,
put on my backpack and took wing.
"Australia for a Year"
Australia means freedom.
I had never been away from home for so long
and for the first time, I took my life completely in my own hands.
The journey was the reward:
Twenty-thousand kilometres on Highway 1,
all around the red continent.
I saw the most exciting things, that you can imagine:
The glittering skyscrapers of Sydney and the fireworks above the opera,
the vivid artist scene of Melbourne and the relaxed night life of St. Kilda.
In wild Tasmania, I travelled for over a month,
always on the search for cheeky wombats and curious wallabies.
Back on the main land I explored dense eukalypt forrests to find koalas
or bushwacked South Australian National parks for kangaroos,
dingoes and emu families, that patroled the remote roads.
In autumn, I drove down the Great Ocean Road,
past the twelve apostles and through the vineyards of the Barossa Valley.
In Adelaide I paused for several weeks, before I continued
for 1200 kilometres through the Nullarbor,
the largest limestone desert in the world
and home of the mysterious Nullarbor Nymph.
In June I spent my time in the lush green shires of Western Australia,
and the remaining winter in Perth, the most isolated, dazzling metropol,
which of all Australian cities is known as the fairest.
When spring came, I continued on the West Coast up North,
past the orange glowing pillars of the Pinnacles Desert
and into the blooming field of wild flowers and golden savannah.
At Shark Bay I fed dolphins and at the Ningaloo Reef I swam
with turtles and sharks along the beautiful coral coast.
Only further up in the tropics, where crocodiles or
poisonous jelly-fish occupied the sea, I stayed on solid ground.
When massive waves pushed against the shores,
I watched surfers perform daring feats,
and on Broomes white beaches and bright red cliffs,
I dreamed of an ever-lasting summer and enjoyed
the warm yellow sun over the turquoise water.
The further I travelled North, the more lonesome it became,
and for days I didn't see anything else but the
craggy formations of the Kimberley.
Isolated road houses and Aboriginal settlements
appeared every hundred k's from nothing.
Places, far away from civilization,
hidden in the dense growth of the Northern parks, between deep gorges,
thousands of water falls and dozens of hot springs.
I observed bush fires consuming the dry vegetation,
endured the sticky tropic climate of the over-grown country town Darwin
and on my way back on the historic train Ghan,
I even survived the surreal heat of Never Never Land.
It was a year full of motion and encounters,
floating with the caravans of backpackers,
travelling between cities and beaches
and living down-to-earth and for the moment.
Wherever I liked the view, I stayed over night,
became friends with other travellers and wild animals,
and got to know a country, that is synonymous for travelling.
A place, far away from daily routine,
where you can always discover something new -
especially life and yourself.
This was my Australia and my desire.
And one day, I will come back.
"Australia for a Year"
Manniac and his car Charlie travel around the red continent.
Travel with us!
